> Which was:  depending on whether you create your tests
> yourself or you let JUnit create them, you need to call super(String)
> or super(). 

That's not true.

As far as I know, Junit calls either super(String) or super() followed by
setName(String), depending on which constructor exists. The first appraoch
exists for backwards compatibility, the second for convenience. In the
Parameterized Test Case pattern, you can use either approach, too.

> And a side question:  if you use the parameterized test
> pattern, it's okay to do your initialization in the
> constructor, whereas setUp() is usually the recommended place
> in the other cases.

You can't pass parameters to setUp, but you still could do some heavyweight
initialization in setUp based on parameters set in the constructor, and I
would recommend it.

Cheers, Ilja
